The gates opened at 5:00 am and the waiting line of boats was already backed up a long way from the ramp. Two of the 284 boats preregistered for the tournament belonged to West-Oak High School's new fishing team. #westoakhighschoolfishing

It was the first student angler tournament of the 2017/2018 bass fishing season, which was sponsored by the Palmetto Boat Center.

All student anglers at the tournament had a good time and were all smiles, even those not bringing in any fish to be weighed. They realized that the important part was not about catching a five fish limit as much as it is about the effort involved.

In bass fishing, like real life, sometimes the satisfaction comes from the "never give up" mentality. With each tournament, the student anglers get a chance to learn a real-life application that will help them long after high school.

Way to go, students!

Note: Life jackets are required to be worn while the combustible motor is running. For more information, contact Kyle Keasler at wohsfishing@gmail.com.

Due to time missed from school on September 11 and 12 during Hurricane Irma, the School District of Oconee County will use the first two scheduled inclement weather days as make-up days. SDOC schools will now be in session on February 26 and March 30 to make up for the two days missed.

Walhalla Middle School and Oconee Academy also missed September 13 due to power outages. To make up for that day, ONLY these two schools will also attend school on Monday, October 23. Buses will run routes as usual for these two schools on that day.

Students who already have plans on those make-up days can send in a note to the school and the absence will be excused. Any absence does count against perfect attendance as the South Carolina definition of perfect attendance is that “students have not accumulated any absences – excused or unexcused.”

State law requires that school districts utilize at least three make-up days before additional days can be forgiven by local school boards or the state. Parents can see the district calendar on the district website at www.oconee.k12.sc.us.

In an effort to encourage reading in general and to motivate students to explore different types of books, the Seneca Middle School Media Center recently hosted a “book pass” for select eighth grade English/Language Arts classes. Students rotated through a series of eight tables, each featuring books from a different genre - non-fiction, realistic fiction, sports fiction, mystery/suspense, fantasy/science fiction, historical fiction, graphic novels and action/adventure.

At each table, students previewed books in that genre and noted ones they might be willing to try. Media Specialist Sydney Jones said, “My hope is that each student will come away with an interest in at least a few new titles they wouldn’t ordinarily have even considered before participating in the exercise.”

Pictured are Gladys Solis and Emily-Ann Ward as they mark their most favorite and least favorite genre of books on an interactive panel.

In keeping with their goal of offering language instruction at the elementary schools, SDOC took advantage of a special program and employed Ms. Linda Sui, the first Chinese teacher, in fall of 2015-16. To increase the amount of time the program was taught in the elementary schools. the district added Ms. Rose Liu in 2016-17.

While working in the district, however, the Chinese teachers realized that many of the books in the media centers at the schools were outdated and perpetuated stereotypes of the Chinese culture.

Recently, a group from the University of South Carolina visited SDOC representing their home country of China. While here, they brought several books to distribute to the media centers at the Seneca area schools.

The students were excited about the books and were especially enthralled with the dual translation showing Chinese characters along with English text.

SDOC looks forward to providing students with accurate views of the world in order to better prepare them for the future – a truly global future. Thank you, Ms. Sui and Ms. Lui!

WOMS students recently held their end of the year school dance where they voted Ben Bryant as Eighth Grade King of the Dance. This is an honor for any student, but is extra special for Ben, a student with special needs.

“I have never seen Ben more proud of something since I have known him,” said teacher Nicole Adams. “It was just priceless to see the joy on his face as he quickly ran to the stage when they called his name. He will forever remember Friday night because of the sweet and caring eighth graders that we have in our school,” she added. “This is a true definition of what it means to be #warriorstrong.”

The middle school years can be difficult for all students. So this is a wonderful yet practical example of the support and caring exhibited by WOMS students. Way to go, students!
